facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1716 of 1972 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1716 of 1972.

facts.text: Appeal is by certificate from the judgment and order dated November 11, 1971 of the Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated November 11, 1971 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 3716 of 1970.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court judgment in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 3716 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated November 11, 1971 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 3716 of 1970.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court held provisions of section 29-A of the U.P. Sales Tax Act inserted by section 15 of the U.P. Sales Tax Amendment and Validation Act, 1971 and section 17 of the Amending Act unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate is directed against the judgment of Allahabad High Court whereby that court held the provisions of section 29-A of the U.P. Sales Tax Act 15 of 1948 hereinafter referred to as the principal Act inserted by section 15 of the U.P. Sales Tax Amendment and Validation Act, 1971 Amendment Act of 1971 hereinafter referred to as the Amending Act as well as section 17 of the Amending Act to be unconstitutional.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Commissioner of Sales Tax v. Ganga Sugar Corporation Ltd. held that section 8-A(4) of the principal Act was ultra vires the State Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in the case of Commissioner of Sales Tax v. Ganga Sugar Corporation Ltd.1 held that section 8-A4 of the principal Act was ultra vires the State Legislature Section 8-A4 read as under 8-A4 . Without prejudice to the provisions of clause g of sub-section 2 of section 14, the amount realised by any person as tax on sale of any goods shall, notwithstanding anything contained in any other provision of this Act, be deposited by him in a Government treasury within such period as may be prescribed, if the amount so realised exceeds the amount payable as tax in respect of that sale or if no tax is payable in respect thereof.

facts.text: Abdul Quader and Co. v. Sales Tax Officer, Hyderabad held that similar provision in Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act was not valid under entry 54 List II.

anchor.surface_text: The Court in that context relied upon the decision in Abdul Quader and Co. v.Sales Tax Officer, Hyderabad.2 it was held in Abdul Quaders case that the State Legislature in making a similar provision, viz., section 112 in the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, could not be regarded as having directly legislated for the imposition of sales and purchase tax under entry 54 List 11 in the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution because the amount though collected by way of tax was not exigible as tax under the law.

facts.text: In 1969 the Uttar Pradesh Taxation Amendment Act, 1969 (U.P. Act 11 of 1969) was passed.

anchor.surface_text: In 1969 the Uttar Pradesh Taxation Amendment Act, 1969 U.P. Act 11 of 1969 was passed. Section 17 of that Act inserted section 29-A which read as under 29-A.-Refund in special cases.

facts.text: Section 17 of U.P. Act 11 of 1969 inserted section 29-A in the principal Act.

anchor.surface_text: In 1969 the Uttar Pradesh Taxation Amendment Act, 1969 U.P. Act 11 of 1969 was passed. Section 17 of that Act inserted section 29-A which read as under 29-A.-Refund in special cases. Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act or in any other law for the time being.in force or in any judgment, decree or order of any court, where any amount is either deposited or paid by any dealer or other person under subsection 4 or sub-section 5 of section 8-A, such amount or any part thereof shall on a claim being made in that behalf in such form and within such period as may be prescribed, be refunded to the person from whom such dealer or the person had actually realised such amount or part , and to no other person.

facts.text: Amending Act was published on August 22, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: On August 22, 1971 the Amending Act was published. A number of amendments were made by the Amending Act in the principal Act.

facts.text: By section 10 of the Amending Act, sub-section (4) and (5) of section 8-A were omitted.

anchor.surface_text: By section 10 of the Amending Act, sub-section 4 and 5 of section 8-A were omitted.

facts.text: Section 15 of the Amending Act substituted section 29-A of the principal Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 15 of the Amending Act was as under For section 29-A of the principal Act, the following section shall be substituted, namely - 29-A. 1 Where any amount is realised from any person by any dealer purporting to do so by way of realisation of tax on the sale of any goods to such person, such dealer shall deposit the entire amount so realised into the Government Treasury, within such period as may be prescribed notwithstanding that the dealer is not liable to pay such amount as tax or that only a part of it is due from him as tax under this Act,

facts.text: Section 17 of the Amending Act contains transitional provisions for deeming and validation consequent upon the deletion of sub-sections (4) and (5) of Section 8-A and the substitution of section 29-A.

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 contains transitional provisions for deeming and validation consequent upon the deletion of sub-sections 4 and, 5 of Section 8-A and the substitution of section 29-A in the principal Act.

facts.text: The dispute relates to the amount which a dealer wrongly realises as sales tax from the customer.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute relates to the amount which a dealer wrongly realises as sales tax from the customer and the question which arises for consideration is whether a State Legislature has the legislative competence to pass a law for the deposit of that amount in the Government Treasury.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court observed that section 17 was dependent upon and interrelated with section 15 of the Amending Act.

anchor.surface_text: So far as section 17 of the Amending Act is concerned, the High Court observed that this section was dependent upon and interrelated with section 15 of the Amending Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Ashoka Marketing Ltd v. State of Bihar held provisions similar to section 29-A unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The above observations were quoted with approval by a six- Judge Bench of this Court in the case of Ashoka Marketing Ltd v. State of Bihar-and Another1 . In that case the provisions of section 20 A of the Bihar Sales Tax Act which were substantially1 1970 26 I. T. R. 254. similar to those of section 29-A now impugned before us, were assailed.

facts.text: Counsel for appellants: N. Kachar, N. D. Karkhanis, K. C. Agarwala and O. P. Rana.

anchor.surface_text: N. Kachar N. D. Karkhanis, K. C. Agarwala and O. P. Rana, for the appellants.

facts.text: Counsel for respondents: Yogeshwar Prasad, S. K. Bagga and S. Bagga.

anchor.surface_text: Yogeshwar Prasad, S. K. Bagga and S. Bagga, for the respondents.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by KHANNA, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KHANNA, J.

facts.text: Section 17 provides that the amount already deposited under section 8-A(4) shall be deemed to be under section 29-A as substituted.

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 provides that the amount already deposited under section 8-A 4 of the principal Act shall be deemed to be under section 29-A as substituted by section 15 of the Amending Act.

facts.text: Learned Advocate General appearing for the appellant State did not challenge the view on section 17.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Advocate General appearing for the appellant State has not, and in our opinion, rightly challenged the correctness of the view taken by the High Court in this respect.

issues.text: the question which arises for consideration is whether a State Legislature has the legislative competence to pass a law for the deposit of that amount in the Government Treasury. In other words, is there any entry in List II or List III of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution under which the State Legislature could make such a law?

anchor.surface_text: The dispute relates to the amount which a dealer wrongly realises as sales tax from the customer and the question which arises for companysideration is whether a State Legislature has the legislative companypetence to pass a law for the deposit of that amount in the Government Treasury. In other words, is there

issues.text: whether section 17 of the Amending Act is unconstitutional as it is dependent upon and interrelated with section 15 of the Amending Act

anchor.surface_text: So far as section 17 of the Amending Act is concerned, the High Court observed that this section was dependent upon and interrelated with section 15 of the Amending Act. Section 17 provides that the amount already deposited under section 8-A (4) of the principal Act shall be deemed to be under section 29-A as substituted by section 15 of the Amending Act.

issues.text: whether the impugned provisions are covered by entry 54 in List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: As the said amount does not constitute sales tax, it is not covered by entry 54 in List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution which relates to taxes on sale or purchase of goods other than newspapers subject to the provision of entry 92-A of List I.

issues.text: whether the provision like section 29A is ancillary or incidental to the collection of tax legitimately due under a law made under entry 54

anchor.surface_text: The argument that provision like section 29A is ancillary or incidental to the collection of tax legitimately due under a law made under entry 54 has no force. Such an argument was rejected by this Court in Abdul Quaders case supra in the following words

issues.text: whether the impugned law would be covered by entry 7 in List III which relates, inter alia, to contracts

anchor.surface_text: Argument has been advanced before us on behalf of the appellant that the impugned law would be covered by entry 7 in List III which relates, inter alia, to contracts. A similar argument was advanced in the case of Ashoka Marketing Ltd. supra and was rejected in the following words

issues.text: whether the law in question relates to trust and can be justified under entry 10 in List III

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it has been argued that the law in question relates to trust and can be justified under entry 10 in List III. We, however, fail to see as to how such a law can be said to relate to trusts.

arguments.claim: State Legislature lacks competence as no entry in List II or List III covers law requiring deposit of wrongly realised sales tax amounts

anchor.surface_text: The dispute relates to the amount which a dealer wrongly realises as sales tax from the customer and the question which arises for consideration is whether a State Legislature has the legislative competence to pass a law for the deposit of that amount in the Government Treasury.

holdings.text: Section 17 of the Amending Act is unconstitutional because it is dependent upon and cannot exist independently of section 15.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Advocate General appearing for the appellant State has not, and in our opinion, rightly challenged the correctness of the view taken by the High Court in this respect. We may not deal with the provisions of section 15 of the Amending Act as a result of which section 29-A was substituted in lieu of the old section 29-A in the principal Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly held s17 ancillary to s15; State concedes and court agrees it shares fate of unconstitutional s15.

holdings.text: The amount wrongly realised as sales tax does not constitute sales tax and is not covered by entry 54 List II.

anchor.surface_text: As the said amount does not constitute sales tax, it is not covered by entry 54 in List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution which relates to taxes on sale or purchase of goods other than newspapers subject to the provision of entry 92-A of List I.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application: wrongly realised amount not actual sales tax payable.

holdings.text: Provisions like section 29-A are not ancillary or incidental to collection of tax under entry 54 List II.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that provision like section 29A is ancillary or incidental to the collection of tax legitimately due under a law made under entry 54 has no force. Such an argument was rejected by this Court in Abdul Quaders case supra in the following words

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Abdul Quader: ancillary power does not extend to forcing payment of non-exigible amounts to government.

holdings.text: The impugned provisions are not covered by entry 54 List II.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the above decision, the contention that the impugned Act would be covered by entry 54 in List II can plainly not be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects coverage under entry 54 based on prior precedents and rejection of ancillary argument; amount not tax.

holdings.text: Impugned law not covered by entry 7 List III (contracts) or related entries 6,13.

anchor.surface_text: Argument has been advanced before us on behalf of the appellant that the impugned law would be covered by entry 7 in List III which relates, inter alia, to contracts. A similar argument was advanced in the case of Ashoka Marketing Ltd. supra and was rejected in the following words

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Ashoka Marketing Ltd.: entries 6,7,13 do not authorise recovery of non-entitled collections.

holdings.text: Impugned law does not relate to trusts under entry 10 List III.

anchor.surface_text: We, however, fail to see as to how such a law can be said to relate to trusts. A trust is an obligation annexed to the ownership of property and arises out of confidence reposed in and accepted by the owner or declared and accepted by him for the benefit of another or of another and the owner see section 3 of the Indian Trusts Act, 1882 . It is plain that a law compelling deposit-of money wrongly realised as sales tax cannot in pith and substance be considered to be a law relating to trusts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pith and substance test: not a trust law despite word 'trust'; mere terminology insufficient; applies s3 Indian Trusts Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: the State Legislature in making a similar provision could not be regarded as having legislated for imposition of sales tax under entry 54 List II because amount collected was not exigible as tax
precedents.cited_holding: We do not think that the ambit of ancillary or incidental power goes to the extent of permitting Legislature to provide that though the amount collected may be wrongly by way of tax is not exigible under the law as made under the relevant taxing entry, it shall still be paid over to Government, as if it were a tax.

precedents.cited_proposition: the State Legislature in making a similar provision could not be regarded as having legislated for imposition of sales tax under entry 54 List II because amount collected was not exigible as tax

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Quaders case supra

precedents.case_name: Abdul Quader and Co v Sales Tax Officer Hyderabad
precedents.cited_proposition: provision requiring deposit of amount collected as tax but not exigible as tax is not ancillary or incidental to collection of tax legitimately due
precedents.cited_holding: where the legislation under the relevant entry proceeds on the basis that the amount concerned is not a tax exigible under the law made under that entry, but even so lays down that though it is not exigible under the law, it shall be paid over to Government... it is difficult to see how such a provision can be ancillary or incidental to the collection of tax legitimately due

anchor.surface_text: Learned Advocate General appearing for the appellant State has not, and in our opinion, rightly challenged the correctness of the view taken by the High Court in this respect. We may not deal with the provisions of section 15 of the Amending Act as a result of which section 29-A was substituted in lieu of the old section 29-A in the principal Act.

In view of the above decision, the contention that the impugned Act would be covered by entry 54 in List II can plainly be number accepted. Argument has been advanced before us on behalf of the appellant that the impugned law would be covered by entry 7 in List III which relates, inter alia, to companytracts. anchor.surface_text: We, however, fail to see as to how such a law can be said to relate to trusts. A trust is an obligation annexed to the ownership of property and arises out of confidence reposed in and accepted by the owner or declared and accepted by him for the benefit of another or of another and the owner see section 3 of the Indian Trusts Act, 1882 . It is plain that a law compelling deposit-of money wrongly realised as sales tax cannot in pith and substance be considered to be a law relating to trusts.

In view of the above decision, the contention that the impugned Act would be covered by entry 54 in List II can plainly be number accepted. Argument has been advanced before us on behalf of the appellant that the impugned law would be covered by entry 7 in List III which relates, inter alia, to companytracts.
